data.title: The `Debug Console` can't read user's input
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:40:39.245Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.62-18.6-default
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.13|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|vscode-auto-open-markdown-preview|hnw|0.0.4|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.9.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. dotnet new console -o hwapp
    dotnet restore
    dotnet run
2. Open it with VSCode, and add some lines (in "main" method) like this:
    `String name = Console.ReadLine();
    Console.WriteLine("Your name is " + name);`
3. Debug it by pressing F5

When the code steps to ` String name = Console.ReadLine();`, it will be paused no matter whatever you input in the Debug Console.
Or it just can't debug console apps? Tell me, or show me how to to do. Thanks.

data.title: Zoom offsets the visible cursor
data.body:
I recently noticed a bug where the visible editing cursor and selection are offset to where VSCode thinks the cursor is. This happens when zooming in and seems to be dependent on the font you are using.

The bug happens for me when using the [Hack Font](http://sourcefoundry.org/hack/) under Linux. Using that font under Windows did not result in an offset of the cursor / selection. Using *Ubuntu Mono* as my font did not trigger the bug, nor was increment the font size instead of zooming.

The following pictures illustrate the issue:

Correct selection using *Ubuntu Mono*:\
![no_offset_far_right](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/328798/25779056/b3b85de2-330f-11e7-8043-e1471577ba4b.png)

Offset selection using *Hack*:\
![offset_far_right](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/328798/25779057/b8b104de-330f-11e7-87bd-31790e2222c6.png)

In both cases `node.getRight()` has been selected and hitting backspace will delete it.

This also happens around the 80 column mark, not just far to the right, note the cursor ontop of the equal sign:\
![offset](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/328798/25779077/58445bf4-3310-11e7-996d-e100be8ea3b0.png)


- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Setup VSCode to use Hack as font.
2. Open a file with content.
3. Zoom (bug may only trigger on some zoom levels).
4. Select text.

Maybe Related:
- #22181

data.title: Fix staging lines to not corrupt line endings when autocrlf is enabled

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Pass the --path argument to git hash-object so that filters are correctly applied when staging lines. This prevents lines with crlf from being added to files that have autocrlf=true. Old versions of git can complain quite a bit if you get into this state.

From: https://git-scm.com/docs/git-hash-object

> 
> --path
> 
> Hash object as it were located at the given path. The location of file does not directly influence on the hash value, but path is used to determine what Git filters should be applied to the object before it can be placed to the object database, and, as result of applying filters, the actual blob put into the object database may differ from the given file. This option is mainly useful for hashing temporary files located outside of the working directory or files read from stdin.

Fixes https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16889

data.title: Word suggestion does not respect editor.wordSeparators
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.4 

Steps to Reproduce:

I have a custom file that separates financial account names using colons. A typical name might look like:

> Assets:Bank:Checking

In my user settings, I modified `editor.wordSeparators` and removed the colon from the list of characters. When I open my custom file and begin typing an account name, the word completion stops after I enter a colon. 

1. Modify `editor.wordSeparators` and remove the colon
2. Create an empty file, put: `Assets:Bank:Checking` on a new line.
3. On another line, attempt word completion for `Assets:Bank:Checking` and witness the aforementioned bug

data.title: Typescript language server will occasionally "refresh" constantly when editing a ts file
data.body:
Occasionally when editing a file, the document will enter a state where it seems like TypeScript is being continually being reset. This get's especially cumbersome as intellisense will flicker in and out and the code lens annotations will disappear and reappear causing the document to jump around.

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Creators Update

I don't have logs or reliable reproduction steps. Next time it happens I'll attempt to get logs. It seems to happen most often when doing edits that but the rest of the document in a "bad" state, like inserting a backtick `.

data.title: Provide a way to permanently dismiss the 'there is an available upgrade' message
data.body:
I might have a very good reason not to want the upgrade. For example:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/26096

Pesterting me every time I start vscode is rather annoying. So please provide a way to silence the message at least until the next upgrade.

Ironically, I would like the upgrade, because it fixes a similarly annoying 'please upgrade git' message.

So, now, every time I start vscode,  I have to dismiss *two* of these, as if one isn't annoying enough.

I think it's necessary to provide settings in vscode to show/hide the context menu in explorer(the menu on file and in directory separately will be better) , that would be more user-friendly, right?

data.title: Visual Studio Code (with the golang extension) very, very slow?
data.body:
Dear Sir,
PROBLEM:
Why is Visual Studio Code (with the golang extension) so very, very slow?

ANALYSIS:
1. I am running Windows 10 on a desk top PC.
Processor: Intel(R) Core(TM) i3 CPU 540 @ 3.07GHz 3.06 GHz
Installed Memory (RAM): 4.00 GB (3.87 GB usable)
System type: 64-bit Operating System, x64-bassed processor

2. I am running Visual Studio Code Version 1.12.1
Commit f6868fce ...
Date 2017-05-04T21:26:50.689Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0

3. I am using the golang extension.

I have the following in a file called helloworld.go:-

package main
import "fmt"
func main() {
    fmt.Println("hello world")
}

I type go run helloworld.go in the terminal area and it takes 11 (sometimes 20) minutes to get a response

Why is it so very, very slow?
I would be very grateful for any advice.

Thank you
Mike

data.title: Adding option to report issues about extensions
data.body:
Implements the feature requested in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/21376

I added the three requested options:

* Added a Report Issue button, next to the Uninstall button, on the Extension view
* Added a `Help: Report Extension Issue` command that displays a quick pick of all extensions with available issue URLs, letting you choose which one to report
* Added an intermediary step into the `Help: Report Issue` command, that will display the extensions along with VS Code, as an option to report an issue.

I personally feel like adding the extensions to the `Help: Report Issue` command is confusing, so I'm wondering if we should just stick with the first two options.

I struggled a bit on deciding the best place to put the common code, let me know if you have any suggestions.

I also simplified a bit the new issue "template" generated by the Report Extension Issue. I removed the extensions table and the isPure parameter. I've added the version of the selected extension in there, as that's interesting to have.

data.title: Caret render position not always updated

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

Move caret around (clicking to new position seems to increase how often this will happen, though it'll occur when using the arrow keys too).

When caret does not move to the clicked position, use an arrow key and observe that the caret position is rendered relative to where last clicked (even though it did not visually move there).

data.title: Freeze when Chrome is rendering 3D scene in the background

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- Chrome Version: 58.0.3029.96
- OS Version: Windows10 15063.138

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Chrome and VS Code with both maximized.
2. Switch to Chrome, open a web page which constantly renders 3D scene on a `<canvas>` element
3. Open the Dev Tool of the Chrome, make sure the focus is on the Dev Tool (open the Console, make sure the input cursor is blinking) while not causing the render process to stop.
4. Switch between VS Code and Chrome (using ALT+TAB), and there will be a great chance that the VS Code freezes for a while when switch back to it.

This problem occurs when I am trying to use VS Code to finish the assignments of my Computer Graphics course, which requires us to use JavaScript and WebGL to create 3D scene and animation.

My implementation will keep rendering even if the scene did not change at all (pretty naive, I know). When I am debugging my work, I frequently switch between Chrome and VS Code, and I noticed that VS Code would freeze for a while when I switch back to it in most of the time. Sometimes the freezing can last for over 10 seconds, so it is really annoying. Interesting to note that this freezing problem never triggered the Windows' "not responding" warning.

I am sure this problem is triggered by the rendering process, since now I am careful enough to switch to another Chrome tab (to stop the rendering) every time before I switch back to VS Code, and the problem goes away. I tried to run VS Code without any extensions using the command `code --disable-extensions .`, but the problem is still there.

You can find my code at [here](https://github.com/Mr-Dai/CSIT5400). The repository contains two assignments, and both of them can trigger this problem on my machine.

If you need any other information, just let me know.
